Response.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial?
Response.Content: A clinical trial is a study performed to test investigational medications, vaccines, or devices for various diseases and conditions. These studies determine if the investigational medication works and is safe to use. Before an investigational medication, or medical device can be made available to the general public, it has to go through several phases of clinical research.

Response.BaseQuestion: What agency regulates clinical trials?
Response.Content: Clinical trials are regulated by the Food and Drug Administration, known as the FDA in the United States. The role of the FDA is to ensure the study team follows a set of principles known as good clinical practices, or GCPs. These principles are designed to make sure the study participants are protected and the study team gets information from the clinical trial that they can potentially use to develop future treatment options.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the phases of a clinical trial?
Response.Content: Clinical trials are typically performed in “phases.” Before an investigational medication can be tested in human subjects, testing occurs in a lab to gather data on whether the investigational medication may work for the disease. Next, the investigational medication transitions to something called a Phase I clinical trial, which typically involves a small number of healthy subjects and is designed to test whether the investigational treatment is safe and to determine what dose should be given. If the results show that the investigational medication is safe, it will move into Phase II clinical trials, where it will be tested in patients with the disease or condition to see whether the investigational medication has any effect on the disease. If the investigational medication works to treat a disease, it will enter Phase III trials, which involve a large number of patients to see if it is safe and effective.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?
Response.Content: There are two main types of clinical trials: Placebo-controlled and head-to-head trials. A placebo-controlled trial means that one group of patients will receive the investigational medication, while a second group, often known as the control group, will receive something called a placebo. Placebo often looks just like the investigational medication but is designed to have no real effect on patients. Placebos are often used in blinded trials, which are trials where the patients do not know whether they are receiving the real investigational medication or placebo. This is done to account for the “placebo effect,” which is bias introduced into the study. Bias may result from a patient’s belief that he or she is receiving a certain investigational medication or the researcher’s belief that a certain result will occur. In a head-to-head trial, one group of patients receives the investigational medication to be evaluated, while a second group of patients receives a different study medication. In most cases, the other study medication is a treatment that is already commonly used by patients. This is often referred to as the “standard of care.” These types of trials allow researchers to see how the investigational medication performs compared to approved treatments. When discussing clinical trials, you might notice that they can also be referred to as “single-blind” or “double-blind.” A single-blind study means that the investigators involved in the study know whether the study participant is getting the investigational medication, but the study participant does not know what they are receiving.In a double-blind trial, neither the investigator nor the study participant knows if the participant is receiving the investigational medication. By “blinding” the trials, no biases—whether real or unintentional—are introduced into the study.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a Data Safety and Monitoring Committee?
Response.Content: A Data Safety and Monitoring Committee, sometimes known as a Data and Safety Monitoring Board, is a group of experts who monitor patient safety and study medication effectiveness data during the course of a clinical trial. The group, which typically includes 3 to 10 members, can recommend that a trial be stopped because of safety concerns or because the study medication is not effective. Members of the Data Safety and Monitoring Committee are usually made up of doctors with knowledge of the disease or condition being treated, statisticians, and sometimes a patient advocacy representative.

Response.BaseQuestion: Should I be worried that my child may be taken advantage of?
Response.Content: In order to conduct a clinical trial, the study team must agree to comply with ethical guidelines designed to protect the physical and mental health of participants, as well as to preserve the integrity of the research. Response.BaseQuestion: Are placebos ethical?
Response.Content: Patients participating in a placebo-controlled clinical trial are told during the informed consent process that there is a chance that they could receive the investigational medication or a placebo while participating in the study. A placebo often looks like the investigational medication, but it has no active ingredient. Placebos are used in clinical research to help evaluate the effectiveness of an investigational medication. Because some participants receive the placebo, the researchers can see the effects the investigational medication has on those who take it. Using a placebo during a study is ethical because the participant has been informed that there is a possibility that he or she will be receiving no treatment. In addition, there are usually protections built into the design of the study to ensure that a patient can be “rescued.” This may include initiating therapy with a medication that is known to be effective in treating the disease that is being studied. Rescue therapy is provided when the patient meets certain criteria that suggest that additional therapy is needed.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
Response.Content: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration requires that potential study participants be given complete information about the planned trial under a process known as "informed consent." This process is designed to clearly inform individuals of the purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to the clinical trial. The informed consent process ensures that participants understand information about the study and how it relates to their own health. It also provides an opportunity for an individual to make a voluntary decision about whether to participate in the study. Following this discussion, you can choose to allow your child to participate in the trial by signing an informed consent form. Even if you sign the form, your child can still withdraw from the study at any time, for any reason. Your child may be asked to sign an assent form that covers the same information as the informed consent form

Response.BaseQuestion: What rights does my child have if he or she participates in a clinical trial?
Response.Content: All clinical trial participants are granted certain rights. For example, the Clinical Trial Volunteer’s Bill of Rights states that you and your child be given enough time to decide whether to participate and to make that decision without any pressure from the people who are doing the research. It also states that you can refuse to participate in the study and stop participating at any time. If you decide not to allow your child to participate, this will not affect the right your child has to receive medical care not related to the research. In addition, this bill of rights states that you have the right to be told why the clinical trial is being done, what will happen, and what you will be asked to do if you are in the trial. You’ll also be informed of any reasonably foreseeable risks, discomforts, or side effects that may occur during the trial and who will pay for any study-related treatment. This bill of rights also gives you the right to have your questions answered by the study team at any time, gives you access to information collected about you or your child, and requires that you receive a copy of the signed informed consent form.
